subject: Re: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: ... I wouldn t say that.  the inappropriate use of patterns , the too-early use of patterns , but overuse?  That s pretty subjective. ... OK, I ll try to
messageBody:
On Wed, 2002-10-02 at 10:33, Berin Loritsch wrote:

> There are antipatterns you have to beware of as well, one such
> antipattern is an overuse of patterns.

I wouldn't say that. the "inappropriate use of patterns", the
"too-early use of patterns", but overuse? That's pretty subjective.

> The TestCase is taken, and by reflection is turned into a TestSuite. So
> is it a TestCase or a TestSuite? That is an important distinction.
> The Model is not readily apparent. A stable and predictable model is
> essential to good design--esp. in this case. I have no problem with
> saying that a TestCollector dynamically creates a TestSuite from a
> collection of TestCases. That is understandable. I do have a problem
> with the TestCase being treated as a TestSuite though.

OK, I'll try to address this one.

TestCase is a mechanism to allow fixture reuse. An instance of a
TestCase builds a fixture, runs a single test, and tears down the
fixture. By allowing TestCase to contain multiple tests (i.e. public
void testXXX() methods) you can share a fixture definition.

Put another way, TestCase is NOT a way to conceptually group tests.
Each TestCase subclass represents a fixture, and contains a group of
tests that run in the context of that fixture. Once you realize this,
you'll find yourself switching (as I did some time ago) from having a
TestCase for each class you are testing (with a overly generic fixture
of which pieces were used by the different tests) to organizing tests
around the fixtures, with less regard for the classes being tested by
each TestCase.

TestSuite is a mechanism for grouping a collection of TestCase instances
and running them sequentially. So, TestCase has the ability to create a
TestSuite containing all instances of itself (using reflection to create
an instance for each constituent test). Also, you have the ability to
create explicit TestSuites by subclassing TestSuite and writing a custom
suite() method. This is useful for collecting together groups of
smaller TestSuites which can be other custom TestSuites, or TestSuites
generated by TestCases.

Both TestSuite and TestCase implement the Test interface. The
TestRunners work with things that are Tests, hence we can point at any
Test (ie TestSuite or TestCase) and recursively run all the contained
tests. The internal nodes are TestSuites and the leaves are TestCases.

I hope that makes things clearer.

Anyone think this would make a good topic for the TDD Coad Letter?
